title: Hainan Volcanic Field
text:
The Hainan Volcanic Field is a <a href="volcanic%20field">volcanic field</a> covering the northern half of <a href="Hainan">Hainan</a>, People's Republic of China. Although mostly <a href="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a>-<a href="Holocene">Holocene</a> in age, minor eruptions have been recorded in the 19th and 20th centuries.
Morphology.
The field is made up of 58 Pleistocene-Holocene <a href="tholeiitic">tholeiitic</a> cones. The two best preserved cones (Leihuling and Ma'anshan ()) are on an East-West fracture line that contains 30 young cones in the <a href="Shishan">Shishan</a> () and <a href="Yongzing">Yongzing</a> regions. Historically, small <a href="Fissure%20vent">fissure eruption</a>s have been recorded from the <a href="Lingao">Lingao</a> and <a href="Chengmai">Chengmai</a> areas.
Eruptions.
Two eruptions have been reported in recent history.
1883 Eruption.
A small fissure eruption took place from Lingao cone in the <a href="Lingao">Lingao</a> area sometime in 1883.
1933 Eruption.
Another small fissure eruption took place from the Nansheling Ridge in the <a href="Chengmai">Chengmai</a> area on June 26 (date accurate to within plus or minus 4 days), 1933. This eruption probably ended on July 8, 1933.
